awd_abstract_narration:
NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award supports fundamental theoretical condensed matter research and education aiming to extend our understanding of nonequilibrium quantum matter. A typical material or electronic device contains an immense number of electrons, which constitute a quantum many-body system - the subject of condensed matter research. The corresponding configuration space, the set of possible states the system can find itself in, is unimaginably large. In thermodynamic equilibrium, the situation is somewhat simplified in that the system occupies states that are close to the lowest-energy state in a rigorously prescribed manner, exploring only a tiny corner of the entire configuration space. This leads to a material with well-defined properties that are dictated by nature and are "non-negotiable."

In contrast, a nonequilibrium system can explore the totality of the huge configuration space and may potentially find itself in a state with drastically modified electronic properties compared to those at equilibrium. Therefore, the ability to control dynamical properties of driven electronic states could open opportunities to design nonequilibrium electronic materials with desired properties, instead of relying on serendipity in equilibrium material physics. This project is focused on exploring fundamental aspects of the underlying physics that would make such nonequilibrium quantum control of electronic materials possible. Of particular interest in this project are many-body quantum systems under the influence of perturbations that are periodic in time, which in practice is often achieved by irradiating electronic materials by light. 

The project achieves broader impacts by bringing together ideas from different fields of physics and mathematics, integrating them into teaching, and communicating them to a wide audience, building on the PI's prior efforts. Mentoring of students will continue and will include a continuing collaboration with the Science Magnet Program at Montgomery Blair High School in Silver Spring, MD, and the historically black Howard University in Washington, DC. The outreach component will also include further development and refinement of PI's massive open online course "Exploring Quantum Physics."

TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award supports fundamental theoretical condensed matter research and education aiming to extend our understanding of nonequilibrium quantum matter. The emphasis is on relating exciting theoretical results and ideas to experiment, and communicating them to a broad audience. The research effort is focused on studies of dynamics of quantum many-body systems. Below is a list of three key research foci: 

1. A periodically-driven rotor is a prototypical model that exhibits a transition to chaos in the classical regime and dynamical localization in the quantum regime. The Principal Investigator will explore interacting many-body generalizations of such nonlinear, periodically driven systems, which are expected to exhibit transitions from many-body quantum chaos to dynamical localization.

2. Recent experiments have observed interesting light-induced states in topological materials, such as Floquet reconstruction of electronic bands by light and a photovoltage and gigantic surface life-time in topological insulators. Motivated by this experimental progress, this project aims to develop a theory of Floquet systems coupled to a heat bath. An ambitious goal here is to identify general principles of Floquet thermodynamics.

3. Solitons are fascinating nonlinear phenomena that occur in a diverse array of classical and quantum systems. Relying on a series of exact results, obtained recently by the PI, it is proposed to consider dissipative dynamics of quantum solitons in superfluids. 

The study of nonequilibrium many-body systems would provide new insights into several classes of physically interesting and technologically important materials and has the potential to deliver results of fundamental and practical importance. For example, an understanding of the long-lived photoexcited states in topological insulators may provide a roadmap for creating novel devices, such as an optical p-n junction and a solar cell, based on light-induced topological surface states. 

The project achieves broader impacts by bringing together ideas from different fields of physics and mathematics, integrating them into teaching, and communicating them to a wide audience, building on the PI's prior efforts. Mentoring of students will continue and will include a continuing collaboration with the Science Magnet Program at Montgomery Blair High School in Silver Spring, MD, and the historically black Howard University in Washington, DC. The outreach component will also include further development and refinement of PI's massive open online course "Exploring Quantum Physics."

por.por_cntn:
One of the grand goals of modern condensed matter research is the discovery of new states of matter with new functional properties. A key outcome of this NSF project is a new paradigm in the search for new functionalities of materials that combines the rich physics of strong electronic correlations in solids with quantum optics platforms based on strong light-matter coupling. It was demonstrated theoretically that interacting condensed matter systems embedded in quantum cavities acquire  new and remarkable properties. Of particular interest is the proposal to enhance superconductivity by coupling materials to cavity photons. Superconductivity is a remarkable state of matter, where electrons flow without resistance. It has found use in a variety of technologies from ultra-strong magnets in MRI machines and levitating trains to practical quantum computing architectures. However, superconductivity is a fragile state which is destroyed by thermal fluctuations, usually well below the room temperature. Recent years have seen much progress in extending superconducting-like states to a wider regime of parameters by optical driving. This NSF project demonstrates that this light-induced transient enhancement can be made permanent by combining superconductivity and cavity physics. First experiments along these lines have showed promising results.

 

Furthermore, this project demonstrated for the first time that light-matter interactions may give rise to a zoo of new light-matter hybrid states – called polaritons. It has been long known that negatively charged electrons and positively charged holes in semiconductors can form bound states – much like a hydrogen atom – called excitons and these excitons can be hybridized with light. The resulting polaritonic entities are very light and according to the old theory of Einstein can form a quantum coherent (Bose-Einstein) condensate at high temperatures (room temperature polaritonic condensates have been reported). This project showed that excitations (so-called collective modes) in interacting quantum materials can be hybridized with light just as well and condensed leading to a new and rich class of quantum coherent polaritonic states. These strongly correlated polaritonic condensates may be of great interest to both fundamental physics and emerging technologies.

 

All in all, this NSF project has succeeded in starting up a new interdisciplinary field at the intersection of material physics and quantum optics. This pioneering research has been performed in collaboration with talented students and postdoctoral researchers, including those from underrepresented groups, and has resulted in 6 PhD degrees in physics being awarded. Furthermore, this NSF project was used to host talented high-school students from a local magnet school – Montgomery Blair School, and helped attract the scientifically talented youth to science studies and careers. Finally, new educational platforms and a massive open online course on quantum physics have been developed and honed. The course has attracted tens of thousands of students from all over the world interested in quantum science.
